issues.title: i586 handling in Leap
issues.body:
In Leap i586 is handled specially due to lack of better options and ideas.
In the main project i586 is enabled in principle.  All packages that are neither in Ring0 nor Ring1, nor have baselibs.conf, nor are required by any of the former are build disabled.

Now this causes two issues in staging:
1. repochecker gets confused if a staging project contains a delete request for package A and an update for package B when only the old package B required A. If B is build for i586 in the main project but not in staging, repochecker would still think B depends on A as it sees the old binaries in the target.
2. ADI stagings are grouped. If one of the packages in the group contains baselibs.conf, all packages are built for i586. That will fail for most of them of course.

So in order to fix both issues I wonder whether the staging tools should mirror the build flags of the main project always? Ie we could enable i586 in staging and when whenever a package get selected into a staging project, the build disable setting from the main project would have to be copied.
Secondly, on accept the command could apply the build flags in the target too. That way stagings could change the build flags.

issues.title: pkglistgen: migrate SLE wrapper scripts to onto migrated python bits
issues.body:
The openSUSE scripts were migrated in #1312 and #1328, but the SLE specific bits need to handle as well.

- [ ] From what I can tell the rings script (http://paste.suse.de/18043) contains additional `rm` commands specifically kiwi globs that need to be handled.
- [ ] Not sure if `~/osc-plugin-factory-coolo/pkglistgen.py` contains any other changes.
- [x] Handle `--ignore-unresolvable` and `--ignore-recommended`.
- [ ] Decide on long-term solution for package clones. Previous was `osc up` which notes to having issues, current does fresh checkout, but for SLE there are a ton of files.

Presumably everything is the same short of squinting at the scripts longer.

Which runs:

Seems like the best route would be to fix `format_spec_file` service, but alternatively ignoring this specific issue since other tools in process should handle.

I've seen a couple delete requests recently that, imho, wrongly ask for maintainer approval.

e.g.: https://build.opensuse.org/request/show/554585

The request was filed by dimstar_suse, member of factory_maintainers group. This group in turn is listed at https://build.opensuse.org/package/users/filesystems/fusecompress as (inherited) maintainer (no local maintainers assigned to the package, only a bug owner)

issues.title: repo_checker: consider enhancing pre-processing or recheck request group before changing state
issues.body:
https://build.opensuse.org/request/show/543659 was moved between stagings after `repo_checker` had started a review cycle. The group in which it originated passed since it was removed and the troublesome binaries no longer present when mirrored. When the `repo-checker` review was re-added it failed, as expected, in the new group.

The groupings are not re-queried after initial pre-processing. Since all requests have to be scanned ahead of time to group by staging this step must remain as it is, but could consider re-checking that group has not changed since the cycle started.

issues.title: manager42: check pending requests
issues.body: before marking a packages coming from e.g. Factory as FORK, check pending requests to the origin project. SLE for example sometimes checks in packages earlier.

issues.title: staging_plugin enhancement: list --supersede --dry-run
issues.body:
list --supersede is very useful to "cleanup" incoming requests with pending one, but it can also cause a "supersede" in a staging you were about to accept (everything is green) or didn't want to touch (very slow to rebuild).

Some --dry-run for the supersede would be useful, to analyze if supercede will be "safe" or not.

issues.title: pkglists: two repochecker users, different cache format
issues.body:
there are several services that run under the old repochecker service on packagelists:
$ grep repochecker /etc/systemd/system/*

The reason they use this user is that they use bs_mirrorfull and used to share the cache with the actual repochecker. Now with the new repochecker user they don't share the cache anymore. Even if they'd run with the same user id they still use a different cache structure in ~/.cache.

issues.title: Decide future of NonFree workflow
issues.body:
It seems the staging tools no longer properly handle requests targeting `NonFree` subproject. I feel like I remember something about this a while back, but likely the recent changes to source checker and what not that load `StagingAPI` will not handle for this as well. The primary bit seems like the staging plugin itself.

For example take a look at the three requests to `Factory:NonFree` currently open.

issues.title: metrics: improve incremental data ingest
issues.body:
All relevant requests need to be walked in order to recreate counts at appropriate times and as such the source data needs to be kept around. This is done via the cache I wrote for `staging` commands. The problem comes when one wants to request new data without having to refetch all data.

The only clean solution seems to be the following (psuedo-code):

- `/search/request?match=in-final-state&order_by=last-updated` (delete last cache page to force require and all subsequent pages)
- `/search/request?match=open&order_by=last-updated` (load all data which should normally fit in 1-2 pages)

The issue is that OBS does not appear to allow ordering to be controlled.

https://github.com/openSUSE/open-build-service/blob/b7109ac7f23bdfc0b7d54376d360100a39d30414/src/api/lib/xpath_engine.rb#L342-L350

Without ordering there really is not anything decent that can be done short of always query all data since a year old request may reach a final state and thus be inserted many pages back.

issues.title: repo_checker: only update staging comment when main repo has built
issues.body: Assuming not an accept should not update otherwise it may do so multiple times since the addition of the `build` hash. Should simply wait until the main repo is complete if same comment and just new hash. This of course complicates the comment matching code a fair bit, otherwise if revert to old style this is not a problem, but need somewhere to store hash. Could store in staging config.

issues.title: repo_checker: decide how to include project level config in build hash
issues.body: If items the whitelist in project level remote config is changed the `repo_checker` should consider different build and re-run. After #1229 all repositories plus the staging meta revision are included. The `cstaging` project meta revision could be included, but given that project is updated semi-frequently for unrelated things it would be preferable to only consider different if config changed.

issues.title: merge update crawler and manager42
issues.body: manager42 queries the package information one by one which is rather inefficient as it requires lots of requests. update-crawler on the other hand already has code to query packages in batch. Maybe it would make sense to combine both programs into one to share code, optionally enable/disable updating lookup.yml resp update function.

issues.title: rebuildpacs.pl: seems to have major pain with _multibuild packages
issues.body:
The HPC team has been converting most of their packages to _multibuild... 

rebuildpacs.pl seems to identify them constantly as 'having trouble' and retriggers them, even though it should not retrigger packages it already recorded in the problems list (on first trigger they are being recorded, then only new stuff should be attempted)

In order to get over the obstacle at all for now, rebuildpacs.pl is hotpacthed on the pkglist vm to ignore some of the packages I have seen being retriggered over and over, which of course bears the risk of masking actual issues

issues.title: tests: decide how to proceed installing additional dependencies on travis
issues.body:
In order to use `osc vc` to generate a changelog entry (rather than re-creating functionality in python) the `build` package is needed. This is available for ubuntu out of `openSUSE:Tools` repo, but will not be the last odd dep that ubuntu may not have. As such it may make sense to run the tests themselves in an `openSUSE` container or inside the `osc build` changeroot. The latter will be tricky to get the local OBS available there, but has the benefit that those tests can run on OBS.

Until this is resolved I have not commited the `check_source.py` tests and have disabled the test suite in `%check` section of spec. The spec may also end up just needing to filter out the integration tests and only run the mock tests. The method of filtering needs to be figured out as whitelisting or blacklisting seems a bit suboptimal.

issues.title: tests/obs: leaks environment variable changes and httpretty setup, affecting all tests
issues.body:
The `OBS` class is implemented as a singleton that never disables `httppretty` which causes any tests that use sockets outside of this mock to fail. This means that the tests in #1207 fail when run as part of suite, but pass when run individually. Bad design to have fixtures that leak environment changes between tests and no fun for a future developer to have to debug.

Not entirely sure what is the best route to fix. The basic requirement is that `httpretty.disable()` be called when test completes. I can hackily workaround by calling that before my test runs, but clearly `OBS` should handle this itself. Since singleton a deconstructor will not work.

issues.title: Setup docker hub build of generalized `osc build` image
issues.body:
Now that I generalized the spec build process (#1126) and worked around the issues with using `osc build` the package dependencies are no longer required to be in the docker image, but are instead downloaded via `osc` during the build. This has a number of advantages one of which is the docker image is essentially static and only changes when `osc` dependencies change.

We can see how this works out for a few weeks, but likely this should be extracted as a stand-alone project for providing OBS pre-builds for use in CI in addition to OBS sync.

issues.title: repo_checker: provide devel project run for maintainers

issues.title: repo_checker: detect old-school "multi-build" subpackage rename and ignore all binaries from target project
issues.body:
A case occurred in Factory of a package with multiple spec files having one of them renamed. The repo_checker has no way to know that it should ignore the binaries from all the previous state of spec files in target project and instead looks for the renamed package in the target project which does not exist so only binaries from the non-renamed packages are ignored.

Short of always making API calls for all updated packges this seems a bit cumbersome to deal with. Interestingly the new `_multibuild` style packages work just fine with this setup since all the binaries produced are associated with a single OBS package container. It almost begs if there are any technical reasons remaining to prevent all such packages from being ported to `_multibuild` as logically it simplifies a number areas the staging tools currently have to deal with or lack.

Perhaps one approach would be to look for all packages in target project that are links to other packages in target project and keep a lookup map. Anytime a request for a package (root package) exists then automatically ignore all binaries from subpackages. Even if the subpackages are detected and ignored a second time the net ignore `set()` would be correct in both the rename and non-rename case without having to explicitly detect it.

The possible edge-case is for packages that do not have all their subpackages duplicated in the rings. Ignoring the ones not built in rings may cause unresolveable install-time dependencies. Obviously this would be another case for enforcing install-time deps to be resolved within rings.

Overall, short of the install-time deps rule being enforced for rings solving this with code may simple trade one problem for another. From what I can see prioritizing `_multibuild` and install-time deps resolved within rings solves both of these problems without requiring a tooling change. Obviously, one of the implications of `_mulitbuild` conversion would be building all subpackages which again seems consistent, but may require discussion.

issues.title: factory-announcer: fails if being redirected to a https site
issues.body:
Factory-announcer has trouble following redirects if there is https involved.

At the moment, I get these redirects:

> curl -vL https://download.opensuse.org/tumbleweed/iso/Changes.20170908.txt -o dummy 2>&1 | grep Location
< Location: http://opensuse.ucom.am/tumbleweed/iso/Changes.20170908.txt
< Location: https://opensuse.ucom.am/tumbleweed/iso/Changes.20170908.txt

a) Factory announcer only follows the first redirect
b) Factory-announcer is hard coded to connect on port 80

issues.title: update-crawler: duplicate requests
issues.body: Seen on patterns-caasp it was submitted from the devel project to sle15. looks like the same sources were later submitted to Factory too and thecked it. After that update-crawler didn't see the sle15 submission as identical anymore. Looks like srcmd5 changed while sources are the same. A solution could be to always call _get_source_package(), not just if the rev in the request is decimal.

issues.title: osc staging: possibility to merge two staging projects
issues.body:
Every now and then, it would be handy to be able to 'merge' two staging projects (more commonly on adi, but sometimes also on letter stagings)

maybe any of our overly complex syntax options already does it - but I could not work out a set :)

Something like: osc staging merge adi:25 adi:65 -> move all packages from adi:25 to adi:65

(currently I do this using a shell function:

```
adimerge () 
{ 
    osc ls openSUSE:Factory:Staging:adi:$1 | xargs osc staging select --move openSUSE:Factory:Staging:adi:$2
}
```

)

issues.title: repo_checker: provide warning about renamed sub-packages that are not properly handled
issues.body: Per discussion in #1044, it seems like a handy feature to explicitly test renamed sub-packages in isolation and provide a clear message about issues.

issues.title: repo_checker: delete: merge with ensure_group() and staging comment
issues.body: Rather than a separate check only performed on `delete` requests, the check should be performed on all delete requests within a group during `ensure_group()` and included in the staging comment. This will also mean that delete requests may block the entire group which makes sense since the other checks may only pass with the delete present.

issues.title: repo_checker: delete: ignore bundle-lang-* for depends_on check
issues.body: The `bundle-lang-*` packages contain auto-generated `BuildRequires` that should be ingored for the purposes of a delete check. Likely makes sense to make a remote config list of prefixes to ignore.

issues.title: repo_checker: cleanup/report back on devel packages once problems corrected
issues.body:
With the addition of a comments API for retrieving own comments (openSUSE/open-build-service#3618), tracked in #1060, it should be simple to cleanup comments that are no longer relevant.

Given maitainers typically discuss problems as replies to the `repo_checker` comment it will leave a deleted parent comment based on standard `ReviewBot.write_comment()` behavior. It may also make sense to post an affirmative `Previously reported problems have been resolved` as I have started doing in staging projects to be clear that things are fine. Those comments could also be removed after a period of time.

Alternatively, the comments could never be removed and only replaced the next time a problem with that package is encountered.

issues.title: repo_checker: consider ensuring that no new issues were added as part of snapshot testing
issues.body:
Another [mail regarding install-time deps was sent to opensuse-factory](https://lists.opensuse.org/opensuse-factory/2017-08/msg00433.html). The new `repo-checker` had [already commented on the devel package](https://build.opensuse.org/package/show/devel:languages:haskell/pandoc), but nothing prevents the snapshot from being released. Considering the huge swath of packages not included in rings problems like this are not too hard to get past the staging process.

Perhaps:

- `repo_checker` result from previous snapshot could be stored somewhere
- openqa could include a test that compares output for the previous snapshot against the current one to ensure no new issues were introduced

Alternatively, the check could be performed at other stages in the workflow, but not sure where it is the most visible.

I understand that some packages break and are not fixed immediately, but seems like its something that should be explicitly acknowledged before going out the door. For problems like this that affect a variety of packages post a big change it would seem desirable to avoid users having to run into these problems. After all we try to test everything else under the sun.

It's rather jarring to receive such a message when trying to update and from experience helping others it does not improve their perception of quality and stability. If a package is in Factory it ought to at least be installable.

issues.title: repo_checker: trim inner section of issue messages to provide better overview
issues.body:
Given the length limit (related #1061) messages have to be trimmed, but important problems can be hidden as a result. As such it may require repeat submissions if the submitter does not notice the other issues.

An example:

```
found conflict of python-azure-sdk-2.0.0-3.3.noarch with python2-azure-batch-3.0.0-3.3.noarch:
  - /usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/azure/batch/__init__.py
  - /usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/azure/batch/__init__.pyc
  - /usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/azure/batch/batch_auth.py
  - /usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/azure/batch/batch_auth.pyc
  - /usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/azure/batch/batch_service_client.py
  - /usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/azure/batch/batch_service_client.pyc
  - /usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/azure/batch/version.py
  - /usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/azure/batch/version.pyc
  - /usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/azure/batch/models/__init__.py
... <many more lines>
```

Would be trimmed after a bunch more lines, but all the other conflicts and install message bellow would be entirely lost. It would be better to trim inner section and keep as many headings as possible.

```
found conflict of python-azure-sdk-2.0.0-3.3.noarch with python2-azure-batch-3.0.0-3.3.noarch:
  - /usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/azure/batch/__init__.py
  - /usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/azure/batch/__init__.pyc
  - /usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/azure/batch/batch_auth.py
  - /usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/azure/batch/batch_auth.pyc
  - /usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/azure/batch/batch_service_client.py
  - /usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/azure/batch/batch_service_client.pyc
  - /usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/azure/batch/version.py
...
found conflict of foo with bar:
 - /some/file
found conflict of foo2 with bar2:
 - /some/file2
```

issues.title: factory-auto: don't post invalid utf8
issues.body: Today we had a problem with the source checker that lead factoryauto to wanting to decline requests. It failed doing that as it apparently tried to post comments that contained invalid utf8. so factory-auto should make sure to only post valid strings.

issues.title: repo_checker: include links to other packages in devel package comments
issues.body: Especially for file conflicts involving other packages having a link to the other package is handy to then start a discussion on the comment present there. This has occurred several times already with maintainers resolving in comments so having a small aid seems appropriate.

issues.title: repo_checker: provide repo arch context on devel comments
issues.body:
The comments on these packages are seemingly incorrect, but actually they are correct.

- [vegastrike-extra](https://build.opensuse.org/package/show/games/vegastrike-extra)
- [vegastrike-music](https://build.opensuse.org/package/show/games/vegastrike-music)
- [vegastrike-speech](https://build.opensuse.org/package/show/games/vegastrike-speech)

```
can't install vegastrike-extra-0.5.1.r1-7.4.noarch:
  nothing provides vegastrike-data >= 0.5.1.r1 needed by vegastrike-extra-0.5.1.r1-7.4.noarch
```

I even checked the caches:

```
rpm -qp ~/.cache/opensuse-repo-checker/openSUSE\:Factory/standard/x86_64/b8e583726f99f2e75c5f96093d935923-vegastrike-data.rpm
vegastrike-data-0.5.1.r1-8.4.noarch
```

The trick is that `vegastrike-data` has `ExcludeArch:    %{ix86}`, but the other packages that depend on it do not. As such in the `i586` repo those packages are not installable. The maintainer was as confused as I was at first. The staging comments already have the arch context, but due to the new method used for parsing and merging the problems for posting on devel packages that context was not preserved. I have considered utilizing the parsing for the staging comments as well. Merging these two code paths likely makes sense.

issues.title: select: --merge do not re-stage requests that were manually removed
issues.body:
It likely makes sense to blacklist such requests from entering the same staging again.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/22943929/29284683-5424da56-80f1-11e7-95cb-d71b07f9b40c.png)

issues.title: factory-news: Shortening overlong changelogs
issues.body:
Whenever a package is being reverted, the news diff generator can't find what is 'new' in the diff and decides to put the entire diff into the mail.

e.g. for snapshot 0810, there was a revert of flatpak from 0.9.1 to 0.8.7 (non-linear diff, top-entries removed)

issues.title: update-crawler: fetch requests already

There should be some grace period before it submits to make sure other bots had a  chance to do automated review, or we even wait until e.g. repochecker is done.

issues.title: repo_checker: provide indication of new dependencies for ring0 packages
issues.body:
Source request: https://progress.opensuse.org/issues/15016:

```
Assume this scenario:

take the package util-linux: it is in ring0
a new submission comes in, that newly adds: 'BuildRequires: procps'
We add util-linux to Staging:A (as it's a ring0 package)
procps is currently in ring1
util-linux will build 'just fine' in Staging:A - as procps is there (from earlier builds)
so the staging eventually turns green
we accept util-linux into openSUSE:Factory, which in turn mean:
util-linux in Rings:0-Bootstrap can no longer build, as procps is now missing there (and we can't bootstrap the OS anymore)
there are two solutions: move procpos to ring0 (not cool: it depends on systemd-mini) or revert the change on util-linux
=> it would be good to see such breakage before we accept and have the issue effectlively in Ring0
```

Likely, a comment on the request and an added review for `factory-maintainers` or similar?

issues.title: repo_checker: handle staging changes after review accepted
issues.body: In the case that the `repo_checker` has completed review of all requests in a staging and then changes are made to the staging all requests should be rechecked. Previously, the old `repo_checker` could approve before even staged so this was not really fixable, but now it should be doable. @DimStar77 suggested some sort of project level attribute that marks the staging as dirty or somesuch. The details of when the individual reviews are accepted vs if the mark is used to block the accept command or what need to be worked out, but definitely seems worth doing.

issues.title: emit and listen to events on rabbitmq
issues.body: OBS is meant to emit events on rabbitmq. Some of our bots should react on that and potentially also emit events themselves. For example TTM could emit when it's moving a snapshot to testing and when releasing it.

issues.title: manager42: clean up dropped packages
issues.body: make a full run remove dropped packages from the lookup file or at least add an option to do that.

issues.title: repo_checker: include duplicate binaries check
issues.body: As noted in #1030 it might make sense to post comments on packages producing duplicate binaries. Given the similar functionality is being added to `repo_checker` for uninstallable issues it likely makes sense to just include duplicate binaries check in the `repo_checker` as it would seem to make sense to be a blocking issue and would resolve the workflow issues surrounding it.

issues.title: devel-project: maintainer command request maintainership for missing groups
issues.body:
As suggested in #1019 it would seem to make sense to have an option to request maintainership for missing groups and have this run as a service on packagelist. This would ensure new devel projects have the appropriate groups added once a package has been accepted. It likely makes sense to cite a wiki page where this policy is indicated, but in lie of that at least a bit of text indicating why this is being requested.

The tool should check for previously declined requests and not repeat, pending human intervention. I would assume OBS would email those in a group about the request and any updates to it. If not then the members should be explicitly cc'd to ensure they see the result.

issues.title: devel-project: automatically prune devel-whitelist once included as devel project
issues.body: Seems reasonable to automatically remove projects from `devel-whitelist` in remote config (#1014) once they are elevated to a devel project.

issues.title: check_source: utilize devel-projects.py built list in dashboard container instead of query
issues.body:
Currently, `check_source.py` uses the following expensive query to check if a new package is from a valid devel project (assuming not whitelisted).

```python
search = {
    'package': "@project='%s' and devel/@project='%s'" % (target_project, source_project),
}
result = osc.core.search(self.apiurl, **search)
return result['package'].attrib['matches'] != '0'
```

Given new devel projects will be whitelisted that provides plenty of time for `devel-projects.py` (runs daily) to generate an updated list before the whitelist is pruned. As such it would seem prudent to avoid such a slow query although it only runs for new packages.

issues.title: repo_checker: delete check should take into account requests in same group
issues.body:
The delete check carried over from the previous checker is a bit too simplistic since it does not take into account the effect of other requests in the same group. Meaning that if package `a` depends on `b` and both have `delete` requests in the same group there should be no issue, but currently the checker will complain that `b` depends on `a` since it looks at the results in the main project.

If anything the simplest way to handle this would be to check the staging project first and use the result if available and otherwise fallback to the project. Likely that is sufficient. Any other issues will be handled by the `installcheck`.

Somewhat related to #277 as the same logic will need to be applied when implementing the run-time check.

issues.title: Create standardized service files for use by IBS and OBS

milestone.title: Re-deploy packagelist bots from rpm package

issues.body:
Given there are two variables for most services a single template variable for a service file is likely not enough. As such pointing to an environment variable file/config file might make more sense. It would be nice if the user could be a parameter based on that file, but guessing that it would not be possible to load environment file in that manor. Alternatively, a wrapper script could be provided to start the desired service using the config file as the appropriate user.

As a different approach the users themselves could also be standardized and created by the package so then they simply need to have their credentials setup for the appropriate OBS instance and user. I would imagine the bots/scripts that run as different users on OBS should also be run separately on IBS so this may simplify things.

issues.title: leaper: prevent non-incremental updates
issues.body: leap should e.g. add leap-reviewers if a change from SLE looks like a revert, eg. sr#507319

issues.title: repo_checker: include non-targeted package messages from installcheck
issues.body:
The current code filters out all messages from `installcheck` not pertaining to targeted packages. This could hide potential problems with packages that depend on the changed packages. It would seem to make more since to filter out any messages present in the target project `installcheck` output found in the dashboard container. Obviously, this could be tricky with stagings being frozen at different points, but perhaps the revision from the time the staging was frozen or nearest revision in time could be used.

Additionally (or alternatively), the non-targeted messages could be included as warnings, but not blocking the review acceptance.

A more expensive option would be to run the `installcheck` twice, once without the staging repo overrides and once with and compare the output. This would be the most straight forward way to ensure an exact comparison with 100% confidence.

issues.title: repo_checker: invoke mirror, cycle, and install checks in parallel
issues.body:
All three of these processes take a long time and are not related so it should be feasible to run them in parallel for a significant performance gain. (targeting the new repo_checker form #964)

It is not clear if allowing `ReviewBot` itself to operate in parallel while `repo_checker` blocks at `ensure_group()` for the same group so each group is only checked once. `ReviewBot` would then loop through reviews until all groups are blocked and un-block as they complete.

Alternatively, the parallelism could be added to `repo_checker` only by a small restructure to call `ensure_group()` as part of `prepare_review()`. This case has the benefit of more direct control, but I wonder if other bots would benefit from running in parallel or if OBS would dislike the number of concurrent requests.

The other consideration is the amount of resources available on packagelists as the checks take > 1GB of ram and lock up a CPU core. Having `installcheck` itself run in parallel would be nice as it takes the longest by far.

issues.title: leaper: collect requirements and ideas for rewrite/refactor
issues.body:
@lnussel and I have bounced around the idea of reworking the leaper bot based on the current usage as the code is rather ungainly.

From performing a large number of `leap-reviewers` reviews it seems clear there are classes of updates that should not require human review (like SLE updates) from the perspective of is the update desirable for Leap. Instead only relevant for technical/legal or maintainer sign off. Otherwise, it simply becomes a nuisance to weed through loads of requests that simply should be accepted.

The leaper bot could be reworked to generate a risk and/or badness index (related #943) and only require human review for packages above a certain threshold. Seems more a nuisance to require `leap-reviewer` reviews of KDE LTS updates which are clearly alright from a leap perspective.

The primary areas for concern of origin changes, delete requests. Origin change include major version updates for packages inherited from previous Leap version. Packages that are tracking Factory or a special Leap devel are unobjectionable from the `leap-reviewers` perspective.

Generally, the sources for Leap packages are from places that have already had human review and the only decision to make from the Leap perspective is do we want to support this or is this compatible with the rest of Leap. Combined with a way to shut-off update crawler requests #942 should make for a much smoother daily operation.

Likely, it makes sense to start developing these indexes and outputting additional information that went into the index and if manual review confirms these indexes then the bot can be switched to utilize the index for deciding when to require the review.

issues.title: leaper: include whatdependson summary in reviews (especially delete requests)
issues.body: Seems like how many packages depend on a package is typically an important indicator of how risky an update would be. Several python packages have been in that category, but short of manually checking or knowing of the top of one's head there is no easy indication.

issues.title: update-crawler: mark packages to no longer receive version updates
issues.body:
A number of python packages are to no longer receive updates, but the burden is on the reviewer to remember that or look around for previous declined request. It would be better to mark, perhaps in origin file, the package to no longer receive automatic update requests via the crawler or at least blacklist say Factory updates.

Thoughts?

issues.title: Create escalation system for build failures and repo_checker discoveries
issues.body: As the last escalation step a bug should be created for packages with build failures.

issues.title: issue-diff: rework issue date check to use date in .changes to properly allow 30 days
issues.body:
As I had done in my original approach, the `.changes` file needs to be parsed in order to use the date from the change entry header to skip issues included in the last 30 days to allow for sync with Factory. The current code uses the OBS API (as suggested), `/source/$project/$package?view=issues` which only includes the dates relevant to the bug itself.

I'll take a look at the original parsing code and either a) find a python equivalent that already exists, b) port the code to python, or c) utilize via external script.

issues.title: [idea] monitor a few packages 'closer' for rebuild triggers required
issues.body:
Reference: https://bugzilla.opensuse.org/show_bug.cgi?id=995367

openSUSE:Factory is (usually) built using rebuild=local, meaning only the packages with source changes are being built (which helps us making daily snapshots posisble)

There are a couple packages that should be handled in a different mode: be retriggered if their deps changed / rebuilt

A typical example here is installation-images:{openSUSE,Kubic}: whenever yast for example changes, this package requires a rebuild, to get the latest installer actually to be used during installation.

I likely need some way to query obs for a specific package has been built with the CURRENT packages of it's dep chain, or if there are differences.

so something along the line
```
diff -u <(osc api build/openSUSE:Factory/standard/x86_64/installation-images:openSUSE/_buildenv) <(osc buildinfo openSUSE:Factory installation-images:openSUSE standard x86_64)
```

note: this does not work, as OBS does give different info in buildenv vs buildinfo... one has version=/release= and the other has hdrmd5= attributes
```
-  <bdep name="yast2-x11" hdrmd5="56f7d2fd56fb83e71a8473b8aa4bcb57" project="openSUSE:Factory" repository="standard" />
+  <bdep name="yast2-x11" version="3.1.5" release="1.4" arch="x86_64" project="openSUSE:Factory" repository="standard" />
```

issues.title: Staging bot 'wasted' a bootstrap chance

Today, I accepted staging :B (contained perl) - then let the bot handle the filling up of the stagings.

To my surprise, the bot chose to put

```
devel

```

in there, instead of giving the various wating ring-0 packages a priority pass on :B - considering that there are much more chances to find a staging space for ruby extensions than for ring0 (those often tend to be blocked a while - just look at :C for gcc7) it would probably be good if the bot could give ring0 packages priority if there is a staging available that CAN be used for ring0 packages (for TW that currently means A, B and C, of which only B and C are under the bots control)

issues.title: Do not allow both a change_devel and submit request for the same target package at the same time
issues.body:
Factory managed to trigger the different source project logic that I added to supersede for Leap. See https://build.opensuse.org/request/show/495521.

- submit
- change_devel accepted
- submit from new devel was ignored per logic

It seems the same code that checks that requests are from a devel project should decline a request of either type that is sent (or in real terms reviewed) after a request of a different type for the same target package. The submitter may then decide the order in which they wish to proceed and decline the original request and re-submit if necessary.

issues.title: Create requests to solve un-resolvable packages where the package does not exist in target project
issues.body:
Using a prioritized list of sources generate a request to submit a new package to the target project.

I do this regularly for Leap. Today I created to requests before stopping deciding it should just be automated.

- created sr#495122: followup for love
- created sr#495123: followup for libguestfs

Combined with #811 description based followup staging should make for a rather nice workflow.

For Leap, priorities should be something like the following (and triggering a required package update makes more sense as well).

- SLE
- Factory

For Factory simply:

- devel projects
  - same as un-resolvable package, otherwise
  - alphabetical order to keeping it consistent (could either skip this or try and fallback to repo inspect)

Obviously, block if existing request for the required package in question.

issues.title: Is ?expand=1 useful for /source/<project> calls that only look at package name?
issues.body:
As discovered in #906 a variety of scripts have a copy of this method with `{'expand': 1}` while `StagingAPI` has effectively the same code without the `expand` option. Looking at the output from the API call the list of packages for `openSUSE:Factory` is identical in length, but includes `originproject` attribute which is completely ignored by the code. The call also appears to run quite a bit slower with the `expand` option so if it is unnecessary as it would appear it should be dropped.

```python
def get_source_packages(self, project):
    """Return the list of packages in a project."""
    query = {'expand': 1}
    root = ET.parse(http_GET(makeurl(self.apiurl,['source', project],
                              query=query))).getroot()
    packages = [i.get('name') for i in root.findall('entry')]

    return packages
```

issues.title: Update Factory staging iso template after all staging are rebased
issues.body: While working on patterns splits in the staging project, we have temporary change on packagelists, should merge them to github once all staging project are rebased with patterns splits change.

issues.title: rebuild: keep track of last build reviewed and auto-skip if same build is last again
issues.body: Basically a way to detect if "nothing has changed since last time I looked" for `staging-bot` to avoid extra calls while still trigger rebuilds in a timely manor.

issues.title: leaper: consider mirroring ignored status for requests pending Factory acceptance
issues.body:
For example [`installation-images`](https://build.opensuse.org/request/show/491875) has a pending Factory request that is marked as ignored and it will remain pending until Factory is accepted. It would seem to make sense to mark it as ignored for the same reason as Factory.

Leaper has the necessary context, but would require giving leaper permission to write to `dashboard/ignored_requests`. Alternatively, this could be added to `ignore` command or similar. Even a special mode of `leaper.py` that would only add to ignored.

If the request is selected it should be unselected. As such it may make sense to be part of `unselect --cleanup` or under a new flag.

Regardless of how it is implemented any reasons for not mirroring the ignored state?

issues.title: Fill cleanup_ring whitelist with special cases and end nodes to remain in ring-2
issues.body:
As is the standard problem with automatic clean up the end nodes in ring-2 will be dropped and the dependencies of theirs that become end nodes endlessly is steps. The reason for packages being in rings presumably is that they are important enough to want to make sure they work together. That case may apply to other rings as well.

With the changes from #847. I performed two steps of ring cleanups on Leap 42.3 for just ring 0 and 1. The relevant changes made are included in a gist https://gist.github.com/jberry-suse/11cbeeb28d56fe4859d7f6d3f1e1400c.

The list of packages to be dropped form ring 2 are candidates for review and addition to whitelist if desired to be kept.

issues.title: select: evaluate supersede logic to determine if still desired
issues.body:
There is supersede logic in select that follows a different path from the logic in `stagingapi`. It only checks if the new request ID is larger than the one already staged. In general this distinction seems arbitrary and for Leap likely makes even less sense. With the exposing of the other `supersede` functionality via its own command that would seem preferred over some sort of logic in `select`.

From reading the code, it would seem it allows for one to do an implicit move from one staging to another as long as there is an open request that is considered superseding (greater ID and same target package). The code shares the path of move which is intriguing.

Unless I am mistake the logic seems a bit off (and the message backwards). The final call:

```python
self.api.move_between_project(fprj, request, self.target_project)
```
for a `--move` makes sense, but supersede:

- `fprj` will be the project containing an older request for same package
- `request` (should be `request_id`) ID of newer request
- `target_project` the argument from command line

The message seems backwards:

```python
print('"{} ({}) is superseded by {}'.format(request, supersede[1], supersede[0]))
# new_request_id (package) is superseded by old_request_id
```

The move code, unless I am mistaken, tries to remove the new request ID from the specified project. This should fail since it is not staged there and so it ends up doing nothing, but prints seemingly misleading message about `superseded` and `moving`.

Assuming no one is running into this since I believe one would have to issue a rather unusual command in order to do so. I simply decided to review while I was tweaking the supersede logic for #842. The original commits reference a "corner case" and the code was changed several times.

Forcing `_supersede()` to always `return None` does not cause any test failures that might help illuminate the reasoning. Has anyone seen the `superseded` message printed from `select` before or have some light to shed on this?

issues.title: ring: create command for making and recording ring changes and process during accept
issues.body:
After discussion this tool would be rather useful in general and likely a precursor to #815.

There are several scenarios to support.

- adding request to ring
  - `select --ring 2 A foo` (enabled instead of disabled)
- changing ring from which a request would normally be placed
  - `select --ring 1 A ring_2_package` (marked as moved)
- adding non-ring request to staging for grouping only
  - `select A foo` (disabled and placed in letter project not DVD like current behavior)
- raising the ring for an existing package without a request
  - `ring A 1 ring_2_package` (move package from ring 2 to 1 in staging A)
  - `ring 1 ring_2_package` (move package from ring 2 to 1 in project rings)
  - `ring 2 ring_1_package` (move package from ring 1 to 2 in project rings)
  - `ring ring_2_package` (remove package from ring 2 in project rings)
- reset ring changes made to a package in a staging
  - `ring --reset A foo` (drops metadata and reverts package to previous ring state)
- reset all changes in a staging
  - `ring --reset A`

Future `select` should utilize the recorded ring changes to override base ring placement. Thus if a package is moved from ring 2 to 1 and a request is then staged in that staging the request will be placed in ring 1.

These commands can be issued from `cleanup_rings` instead of the command pairs that are currently issued. `accept` will then apply the changes made in a staging to the project rings. For example:

- `select --ring 2 A newdep`
- `ring A 1 moving_up_in_the_world` (currently in ring 2)
- `accept A`

Would result in:

- normal `accept` behavior
- `newdep` added to ring 2 in project rings
- `moving_up_in_the_world` moved from ring 2 to ring 1 project rings

Having a command to print out ring changes almost like `check` or a `status` command would seem handy. For now this likely makes sense to just include in `ring` command.

`ring A`

Prints recorded ring changes to staging `A` or indicates if there are none.

issues.title: rings: tool similar to cleanup_rings, but to make ring changes in stagings
issues.body:
Seems like the regular ring changes should be fairly straight forward to automate. Look for un-resolvable packages and see if they there exists a package already in the project (or potentially in open requests) that would provide what is needed and move it to the same ring.

Could be a manual tool like cleanup or automated if either documents changes or easy to tell.

issues.title: select: pickup followup requests based on description or for a failing to build package
issues.body:
Followup request, those created after issues are seen in a staging, are quite common and would nice to have a more automated method for handling them. Using a special syntax in the description text seems like a nice convenience.

Some possible examples/patterns (perhaps support a few):

- Followup for KDE:Frameworks5 in Staging:E.
- (Stage|Place) in Staging:E
- (Followup )?for(.* in)? Staging:E

These followup requests could be restricted in a few ways to help alleviate abuse and what not.

- Restricted to project/package maintainers so a slightly more trusted user which would prevent random requests from being created and staged all over. Although, likely the request would end up being duplicate and ignored anyway.
- Maintain the automatic 8 hour staging window or if staging is in the state `failed`.

If a request is made for a package failing to build in only one of the stagings, or if not too tricky a dependency of a failing package, it should be placed in that staging.

issues.title: select: place requests in staging where that package is broken or non-none strategy and broken staging
issues.body:
As a pre-step to either `select` or as a new command, consider broken stagings. The following two examples should clarify the intention.

- Staging:A
  - xmlgraphics-fop build fails
- Staging:C
  - devel @ KDE:Frameworks5
  - digikam builds

Relevant backlog:

- xmlgraphics-fop
- photo-lib-foo from KDE:Frameworks5
- digikam from KDE:Frameworks5

Select:

- xmlgraphics-fop -> Staging:A
- photo-lib-foo -> Staging:C
- digikam -> Staging:C

Essentially, a failed staging merge condition. Currently, the only merge occur as followups to initially staging while a staging is still building. This would handle followup requests to resolve issues after building completes.

issues.title: Consider a new review group specifically for SLE -> Factory changes in Leap
issues.body:
The majority of requests I tend to know to accept or reject and escalate when unsure, but the common escalation case is SLE -> Factory changes of which someone with insight should respond. The first question that seems to be asked is _why_ which could also be ask/indicated in the leaper output to ensure the answer is stated in description or comment. Having a dedicated review queue seems to make more sense than me adding comments to such requests as I come across them.

Additionally, for any other type of requests could also be manually placed in that queue as escalation.

issues.title: considering breaking out `select --add` as separate command
issues.body:
The select logic seems a bit odd since it basically has the `--add` option which does not perform a select, but instead adds packages to a project's pseudometa.

```python
if opts.add:
    api.mark_additional_packages(target_project, [opts.add])
else:
    SelectCommand(api, target_project) \
        .perform(requests, opts.move, opts.from_, opts.no_freeze)
```

```python
meta['add_to_repo'] = sorted(additionals)
self.set_prj_pseudometa(project, meta)
```

I am not familiar with what `add_to_repo` is achomplishing as it is not referenced anywhere else in the codebase. Is this still utilized and if so should it be moved out of select in a similar fashion to moving `list --supersede` into a separate command in #738.

issues.title: Provide `git rebase - i` style tool for re-arranging requests
issues.body: A slight extension of the existing interactive proposal feature (`osc staging select -i`) would be to fill the proposal with the current state of stagings and the backlog to allow the user to move requests (lines) to a different destination. Should not be that difficult.

issues.title: Provide overview/log of  staging related actions
issues.body:
Having an idea of what actions were taken by humans vs automated tools will likely be handy in understanding what is going on. This information could be either directly stored by the staging related tools or sourced from the OBS database through `obs_factory`.

Rough example:

- bot select 96 KDE:Applications to C
- DimStar unselect kate due to upstream license issue
- bot triggered 4 rebuilds in C
- lnussel accept C

The strategy information would likely be handy to display in the dashboard as well.

issues.title: diagnose: provide tool similar to `git bisect` to determine packages at fault
issues.body:
It seems feasible to have a tool that tries to figure out which packages cause build failures in a particular staging to:

1) aid human in diagnoses
2) potentially remove troublesome packages from staging (and into another) to allow acceptance

Potential information used by total:

- build requirement tree
- broken package list and build logs

As a first draft perhaps just a brute force removal of packages to see which combinations work.

The primary benefit of such a tool, even if relatively dumb, is that build machine time can be exchanged for some time spent by humans in initial debugging. Additionally, non-troublesome packages can be expedited to acceptance.

It might also make sense to have a special staging dedicated to the diagnosis tool so that it does not actively change a proper letter staging so a human can operate simultaneously.

issues.title: freeze: add conditions to allow for automatic freeze
issues.body:
Likely will have similar set of conditions to #727 (accept).


Seems that was part of `select` at one point, but removed with a note in commit about addition proper conditions.

```python
        # If the project is not frozen enough yet freeze it
        if not (no_freeze or self.api.prj_frozen_enough(self.target_project)):
            print('Freeze the prj first')
            return False
            # FreezeCommand(self.api).perform(self.target_project)
```

issues.title: accept: add conditions to allow for automatic acceptance
issues.body:
- discuss and collect current conditions applied manually
- review @DimStar77 [script](/DimStar77/openSUSE-helpers/blob/master/Tumbleweed-Dev-Scripts/accept_green_stagings.sh)

Accepting green stagings automatically has the benefit of clearing up stagings which can then be used in automated proposals.

issues.title: Utilize request_splitter proposal generation/merging for adi command
issues.body:
The adi workflow, although more constrained, could benefit from the use of the `request_splitter` for the actual select process. Currently, the grouping phase has been replaced to use the `request_splitter` but the actual `select` portion is done directly.

Once converted the `--merge` option would be handy to allow devel project owners to issue additional submit requests and have them automatically staged with the others. I have had to do this manually several times for Leap.

Utilizing strategies may also benefit the adi stagings if there are common pairings that should be observed or packages kept alone.

issues.title: Reminder: utilize project.remoteurl xpath engine addition once deployed to IBS
issues.body: The hardcoded config listing openSUSE.org link can be replaced with project search openSUSE/open-build-service#2612, but I imagine this will be a few months out.

issues.title: make factory announcer more generic
issues.body:
the factory announcer needs to be reworked to
- support other architectures such as s390
- support other distributions like Leap
- maybe work on the ftp tree instead of DVD

issues.title: Consider allowing ring requests to be marked as ready and unstaged like adi
issues.body: It seems like the same workflow used by adi stagings could be used for letter stagings in that once the staging is acceptable the requests could be marked "ready to accept" and the staging cleared. This would allow the stagings to be utilized even if the conditions are not right for accepting the requests into the project (ie waiting for Factory to finish building to kick off a snapshot). This would free up those stagings for new requests instead of holding up the process.

issues.title: maintbot opens duplicate reviews
issues.body:
"Submission by someone who is not maintainer in the devel project. Please review"
Duplicate reviews can be added if >1 package comes from the same project and the packages inherit the maintainers from the project.
e.g. https://build.opensuse.org/request/show/401699

```
Review: new Project: KDE:Extra
Submission by someone who is not maintainer in the devel project. Please review
new Project: KDE:Extra
Submission by someone who is not maintainer in the devel project. Please review
```

Ideally only one review is opened.

issues.title: check disturl won't work if it has a hack somewhere to change specfile
issues.body:
eg. https://build.opensuse.org/package/view_file/Base:System/glibc.i686/_link?expand=0

```
<link package="glibc" cicount="copy">
  <patches>
    <topadd>
ExclusiveArch:  i586 i686
BuildArch:      i686
%{expand:%%global optflags %(echo "%optflags"|sed -e s/i586/i686/) -march=i686 -mtune=generic}
</topadd>
  </patches>
</link>
```

it had <topadd> block, so disturl won't consistently to linked package. just a note here.

issues.title: abichecker: need to handle failed
issues.body:
need to handle failed and decline:
https://github.com/openSUSE/osc-plugin-factory/blob/master/abichecker/abichecker.py#L893

issues.title: check_tags_in_requests.py confused by .changes files in tarballs
issues.body: check_tags_in_requests.py uses osc.core.request_diff to request a diff for the request it's processing. That api call however always also diffs contents of tarballs which may confuse the bot if tarballs also contain .changes files. See also https://github.com/openSUSE/open-build-service/issues/949

issues.title: repo_checker: delete: check install-time dependencies
issues.body: factory-repo-check.pl fails to check for recomended package which already casued issues when microcode_ctl was removed from factory - see: https://build.opensuse.org/request/show/265522

commit.message:
repo_checker: package_comments(): provide option to post on target package.

For SLE where devel projects are not utilized post on the target packages
directly. Posting on the devel projects might make sense, but would pose
the risk of exposing IBS information on OBS prematurely.

repo_checker: package_comments(): switch to devel_project_fallback().

This allows Leap to post to devel projects based on Factory.

repo_checker: package_comments(): support mutiple target projects.

This allows both Factory and Leap to make comments to devel projects.

ReviewBot: comment_write(): provide bot_name_suffix parameter.

Cleanly allows for multiple comments from the same tool on one entity.
repo_checker: package_comments(): include link to target package.

check_source: add_role: utilize devel project fallback.

Otherwise, for Leap the message will always print None/None.

since they are always present and do not constitute a non-quick review.

taken from the project configuration and repo-checker from config.

commit.message:
osclib/stagingapi: detect baselibs.conf in adi package and ensure archs enabled.

Otherwise, the baselibs are not built and repo-checker cannot verify the
setup.

check_source: load target project config during check_action_delete().

Otherwise, causes fatal crash trying to access self.repo_checker.
osclib/conf: allow devel projects to utilize tools that require conf.
osclib/stagingapi: load_file_content(): provide optional revision param.
osclib/stagingapi: load_file_content(): convert to makeurl() query builder.
tests/ReviewBot_tests: add test_dryrun().
tests/ReviewBot_tests: add test_only_replace_none().
tests/ReviewBot_tests: add test_workflow() complex test.
tests/ReviewBot_tests: add test_basic_logger() as initial test.
tests/comment_test: add test_delete_nested().
tests/comment_test: add test_delete_batch().
tests/comment_test: add test_basic() against OBSLocal.
tests/comment_test: move COMMENT* constants to file level.

tests/OBSLocal: re-parse config and reset authentication when changing user.

Previously, the user was changed, but the authentication not reset. For
osc.core calls made within the text context they would still run as Admin
while separate processes (like scripts) would run as the desired user. As
such this was not an issue before since only scripts were meant to run as
a different user.
tests/OBSLocal: setup test separate cookiejar.
tests/comment_tests: add test_comment_find().
tests/comment_tests: add test_remove_marker().
tests/comment_tests: add test_add_marker().

repochecker: filter out self requirement

When handling delete requests, filter out build requirements on the
package itself. Java for example uses it's previous build to
bootstrap itself.

useful for debugging to limit reviews to a specific group

and expiring via existing code.

Don't die on delete requests

verification.payload:
tree 705cf57bb7836337e4d3a88a17e066d54132f1f6
parent 3e191caa84a7dddce399c62dda80caeefd358d16

committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1510266319 -0600

Merge pull request #1240 from lnussel/master

Don't die on delete requests

commit.message:
metrics: rework to store points as named tuple and write in batches.

Savings of around 400MB per 10,000 requests. Using a named tuple was the
original approach for this reason, but the influxdb interface requires
dict()s and it seemed silly to spend time converting them. Additionally,
influxdb client already does batching.

Unfortunately, with the amount of data processed for Factory that will
continue to grow this approach is necessary. The dict() final structures
are buffered up to ~1000 before being written and released. Another
benefit of the batching is that influxdb does not allocate memory for the
entire incoming batch.

metrics: rework request pagination to provide as generator.

This prevents the memory required to process to be enough to load all
parsed request element trees at once. Instead only one page of requests
is loaded at a time and the memory freed after processed. The end result
is the memory consumption reduced by just over 20% (current Factory drops
by around 2.5GB).

metrics: call ET.clear() to release unneeded memory used by search result.

Roughly 1800MB per 10,000 requests saved.

commit.message: ttm: publish non-oss for Leap 15 too

Don't die on delete requests

Perform src_project checks only on actions that actually have a
src_project

repo_checker: review failed stagings with only openQA failures.

Build failures may cause false negatives in repo_checker results, but
openQA failures are not relevant and should be ignored.
metrics/grafana/review: include opensuse-review-team who graphs.
metrics/grafana/review: default to openSUSE:Factory.
metrics/grafana/review: disable annotations by default.
metrics/grafana/staging: "Project stats" to "Totals"
metrics/grafana/staging: remove 1s interval as it causes RAM issues.
metrics/grafana: standardize title prefix with 'OSRT: '.
dist/ci: grafana dir must be owned by grafana user since it writes lock.
dist/spec: correct metrics postun to reference systemctl by absolute path.

metrics: prefix release schedule file with source dir path.

Otherwise, when deployed via package and run via /usr/bin the files are
not found.

Merge pull request #1225 from jberry-suse/memoize-key-include-all-args

osclib/memoize: include first argument, sometimes instance, in cache key.

osclib/memoize: include first argument, sometimes instance, in cache key.

Otherwise, multiple StagingAPI instances which are unique per project
will share caches for short-hand projects. For example:

StagingAPI.project_status('adi:1') called on two different instances will
share a cache.

Merge pull request #1207 from jberry-suse/obs-docker-compose-test-rebase

Provide local OBS setup, base data creation, test harness, and initial set of tests.
tests/OBSLocal: invoke scripts using `coverage` to include in report.
tests/OBSLocal: split out execute() to provide osc and generic versions.

tests/OBSLocal: include assertOBS() to clarify OBS status before test.

Otherwise, end up with first OBS call in test failing which does not make
the issue as clear to understand.
tests/OBSLocal: add email and include spaces in generated oscrc file.
tests/OBSLocal: rework OSCRC handling to use non-default file.
tests/OBSLocal: add workaround for obs.py leakage.
travis: before_cache: include -R in chmod .docker-tmp.
obs_clone: remove whole repositories rather than just path when fenced.
obs_clone: provide --cache feature.
osclib/cache: allow  ttl of 0 to prevent caching.
dist/spec: disable `make check` during %check until integration tests resolved.
Exclude .open-build-service/ from docker, flake8, and git.
travis: provide local OBS setup and clone base data.
tests/devel_project: provide basic test against local OBS.
tests/OBSLocal: provide based class for testing against local OBS.
obs_clone: clone projects and dependencies between OBS instances.
devel-project: list: only remove self if in devel project list.

Merge pull request #1216 from lnussel/pkglistgen

pkglistgen: skip one cycle when undeleting

osclib/conf: prefer already parsed conffile over OSC_CONFIG env variable.

This is consistent with expected behavior when using:
  osc.core.conf.get_config(override_conffile...)

Also removes the need to change the environment in OBS() which removes a
leak.

tests/obs: move Cache.delete_all() after CACHE_DIR changed.

Otherwise, the real caches are cleared whenever tests are run.
pkglistgen: dont mirror debug packages
pkglistgen: skip one cycle when undeleting
pkglistgen: Output overlapping packages as yaml

pkglistgen: Allow new recommended flag to take over recommends

Useful not to duplicate packages in both patterns and package list
pkglistgen: Ignore modules recursively
pkglistgen: Implement UNWANTED support
pkglistgen: Do not ignore recommendes from other modules

pkglistgen: Have update command exit 1 if it updated something

The idea is to be able to determine if it's useful to run solve command
pkglistgen: Create an unsorted.yml and output duplications

Merge pull request #1196 from lnussel/pkglistgen

pkglistgen: shell scripts to actually commit

Merge pull request #1215 from jberry-suse/travis-cache

Travis improve caching by installing realpath and enabling pip cache
travis: chmod .docker-tmp so non-root can read for caching.

travis: extend cache timeout to 7 days.

Since storing rpms that change relatively rarely and will auto clear.

travis: optimize `osc build` cache by removing build-root.

Locally it the cache will still remain for optimimal speed when developing.
travis: enable pip cache.

travis: install realpath to allow docker-run to correctly mount volume.

In turn caching of `osc build` temporary directories works.

File "/home/coolo/.osc-plugins/osc-staging.py", line 14, in <module>

I updated the README.asciidoc:

ln -sr ./stagingapy.py ~./oscrc/
I did create the link - but strace of osc reveals that .osc-plugins is not looked into it for modules

Uhm. Is true that I didn't see the directory in the sys.path, but worked consistently in my desktop. I guessed that cmdline include all the .py from this directory, and the net effect was equivalent as an indirected import. But looks like that I can't trust this mechanism.
I will change this tomorrow mangling the sys.path. We will still need the ln -s.
why lastbuild=1? you only pass repositories in finished state anyway. lastbuild=1 will hide "expansion errors" to you because lastbuild=1 only checks for the logfile of - well, the last build.

Looks like that check_output is not included in Python 2.6. Because is a test maybe we can use Popen only in this function (http://stackoverflow.com/questions/4814970/subprocess-check-output-doesnt-seem-to-exist-python-2-6-5)
who cares for python 2.6 anyway?
Not me, of course. But will be the one supported in SLE12.

huh? No. even 11.3 already had python 2.7 - SLE12 even considered moving to python3. 

Python 2.6 is stone age

That results in double encodings if url has been prepared by means of makeurl (as it should be).

Currently, ttm fails for me with:

urllib2.HTTPError: HTTP Error 400: packid '_product%3AopenSUSE-ftp-ftp-i586_x86_64' is illegal

url was already encoded, then http_GET adds an additional encoding, resulting in asking for an invalid package
This is the reason why the tests are failing.

+
+import argparse
+import itertools
+import logging
+import sys
+from xml.etree import cElementTree as ET
+
+import osc.conf
+import osc.core
+
+from osclib.memoize import memoize
+
+OPENSUSE = 'openSUSE:42'
+SLE = 'SUSE:SLE-12:Update'
+
+makeurl = osc.core.makeurl
+http_GET = osc.core.http_GET
+
+
+class UpdateCrawler(object):
+    def __init__(self, from_prj, to_prj):
+        self.from_prj = from_prj
+        self.to_prj = to_prj
+        self.apiurl = osc.conf.config['apiurl']
+        self.debug = osc.conf.config['debug']
+
+    def get_source_packages(self, project, expand=False):
+        """Return the list of packages in a project."""
+        query = {'expand': 1} if expand else {}
+        root = ET.parse(
+            http_GET(makeurl(self.apiurl,
+                             ['source', project],
+                             query=query))).getroot()
+        packages = [i.get('name') for i in root.findall('entry')]
+        return packages
+
+    @memoize()
+    def _get_source_package(self, project, package):
+        return http_GET(makeurl(self.apiurl,
+                                ['source', project, package],
+                                {'view': 'info'})).read()
+
+    def get_source_verifymd5(self, project, package):
+        """ Return the verifymd5 of a source package."""
+        root = ET.fromstring(self._get_source_package(project, package))
+        return root.get('verifymd5')
+
+    def get_update_candidates(self):
+        """Get the grouped update list from `fron_prj` project.
+
+        Return a list of updates for every package, including only the
+        last update for every package. Every element is a tuple, where
+        the first element is the name of the package and the second
+        one the most update version of the package:
+        [
+          ('DirectFB', 'DirectFB.577'),
+          ('MozillaFirefox', 'MozillaFirefox.544'),
+          ('PackageKit', 'PackageKit.103'),
+          ...,
+        ]
+
+        """
+        # From the list of packages, filter non-updates and the
+        # 'patchinfo'
+        packages = self.get_source_packages(self.from_prj)
+        packages = [i for i in packages
+                    if not i.startswith('patchinfo') and i.split('.')[-1].isdigit()]
+        # Group by package name and revert the order of updates
+        updates = [list(reversed(list(i)))
+                   for _, i in itertools.groupby(packages,
+                                                 lambda x: x.split('.')[0])]
+        # Get the last version of every package
+        updates = [(i[0].split('.')[0], i[0]) for i in updates]
+        return updates
+
+    def _submitrequest(self, src_project, src_package, dst_project,
+                       dst_package, msg):
+        """Create a submit request."""
+        states = ['new', 'review', 'declined']
+        reqs = osc.core.get_exact_request_list(self.apiurl,
+                                               src_project,
+                                               dst_project,
+                                               src_package,
+                                               dst_package,
+                                               req_type='submit',
+                                               req_state=states)
+        res = None
+        if not reqs:
+            res = osc.core.create_submit_request(self.apiurl,
+                                                 src_project,
+                                                 src_package,
+                                                 dst_project,
+                                                 dst_package,
+                                                 message=msg)
+        return res
+
+    def submitrequest(self, src_package, dst_package):
+        """Create a submit request using the osc.commandline.Osc class."""
+        src_project = self.from_prj
+        dst_project = self.to_prj
+        msg = 'Automatic request from %s by UpdateCrawler' % src_project
+        self._submitrequest(src_project, src_package, dst_project,
+                            dst_package, msg)
+        raise Exception()
+
+    def crawl(self):
+        """Main method of the class that run the crawler."""
+        updates = self.get_update_candidates()
+
+        packages = set(self.get_source_packages(self.to_prj, expand=True))
+        to_update = []
+        for package, update in updates:
+            if package not in packages:
+                logging.info('Package %s not found in %s' % (package, self.to_prj))
+                continue
+
+            md5_from = self.get_source_verifymd5(self.from_prj, update)
+            md5_to = self.get_source_verifymd5(self.to_prj, package)
+            if md5_from != md5_to:
+                to_update.append((package, update))
+                logging.info('Package %s marked for update' % package)
+            else:
+                logging.info('Package %s not marked for update' % package)
+
+        for package, update in to_update:
+            res = self.submitrequest(update, package)
+            if res:
+                logging.info('Created request %s for %s' % (res, package))
+            else:
+                logging.error('Error creating the request for %s' % package)
+
+
+def main(args):
+    # Configure OSC
+    osc.conf.get_config(override_apiurl=args.apiurl)
+    osc.conf.config['debug'] = args.debug
+
+    uc = UpdateCrawler(args.from_prj, args.to_prj)
+    uc.crawl()
+
+if __name__ == '__main__':
+    description = 'Create SR from SLE to the new openSUSE:42 project for '\
+                  'every new update.'
+    parser = argparse.ArgumentParser(description=description)
+    parser.add_argument('-A', '--apiurl', metavar='URL', help='API URL')
+    parser.add_argument('-d', '--debug', action='store_true',
+                        help='print info useful for debuging')
+    parser.add_argument('-f', '--from', dest='from_prj', metavar='PROJECT',
+                        help='project where to get the updates (default: %s)' % SLE,
+                        default=SLE)
+    parser.add_argument('-t', '--to', dest='to_prj', metavar='PROJECT',
+                        help='project where to submit the updates (default: %s)' % OPENSUSE,
+                        default=OPENSUSE)
+
+    args = parser.parse_args()
+
+    # Set logging configuration
+    logging.basicConfig(level=logging.DEBUG if args.debug
+                        else logging.INFO)
+
+    sys.exit(main(args))

+        self.debug = osc.conf.config['debug']
+

+        """Return the list of packages in a project."""
+        query = {'expand': 1} if expand else {}
+        root = ET.parse(http_GET(makeurl(self.apiurl,['source', project],
+                                 query=query))).getroot()
+        packages = [i.get('name') for i in root.findall('entry')]
+        
+        return packages
+

+        u = makeurl(self.apiurl,['source', new_prj, package], query=query)
+        root = ET.parse(http_POST(u)).getroot()
+        old_srcmd5 = root.findall('old')[0].get('srcmd5')
+        logging.debug('%s old srcmd5 %s in %s' % (package, old_srcmd5, old_prj))
+        new_srcmd5 = root.findall('new')[0].get('srcmd5')
+        logging.debug('%s new srcmd5 %s in %s' % (package, new_srcmd5, new_prj))
+        # Compare srcmd5
+        if old_srcmd5 != new_srcmd5:
+            # check if it has diff element
+            diffs = root.findall('files/file/diff')
+            if diffs:
+                return ET.tostring(root)
+        return False
+

+        old_packages = self.get_source_packages(self.old_prj)

+

+                have_diff = self.check_diff(pkg, self.old_prj, self.new_prj)

+                    if self.verbose:

+from __future__ import print_function
+
+import datetime
+import hashlib
+import os
+import osc.core
+import re
+import shutil
+import sys
+import urlparse
+from StringIO import StringIO
+from osc import conf
+from osc.core import urlopen
+from time import time
+
+try:
+    from xml.etree import cElementTree as ET
+except ImportError:
+    import cElementTree as ET
+
+
+def http_request(method, url, headers={}, data=None, file=None):
+    """
+    Wrapper for osc.core.http_request() to provide GET request caching.
+    """
+
+    if method == 'GET':
+        ret = Cache.get(url)
+        if ret:
+            return ret
+    else:
+        # Logically, seems to make more sense after real call, but practically
+        # it should not matter and makes the apitests happy when dealing with
+        # request acceptance which causes a GET to determine target project.
+        Cache.delete(url)
+
+    ret = osc.core._http_request(method, url, headers, data, file)
+
+    if method == 'GET':
+        ret = Cache.put(url, ret)
+
+    return ret
+
+
+class Cache(object):
+    """
+    Provide a cache implementation for osc.core.http_request().
+
+    The cache takes a list of regular expression patterns and time to live (ttl)
+    for API paths. In addition to the ttl the project context is taken into
+    account when available in order to expire all caches related to a project
+    when the remote server indicates a change was made more recently than the
+    local cache reflects. This provides a fairly robust cache that can handle
+    multiple users changing the same projects.
+
+    Cannot safely cache, for lengthy periods, paths that can update without user
+    interaction or that do not trigger the project updated timestamp to change.
+    Such paths include anything related to build status. When a source package
+    is updated the linked packages do not trigger an update of their project. As
+    such sources cannot be reliably cached for too long.
+
+    Any paths without a project context will be cleared when updated using this
+    cache, but obviously not for other contributors.
+    """
+
+    CACHE_DIR = os.path.expanduser('~/.cache/osc-plugin-factory')
+    TTL_LONG = 12 * 60 * 60
+    TTL_SHORT = 5 * 60
+    TTL_DUPLICATE = 3
+    PATTERNS = {
+        # Group members cannot be guaranteed, but change rarely.
+        '/group/[^/?]+$': TTL_SHORT,
+        # Clear target project cache upon request acceptance.
+        '/request/(\d+)\?.*newstate=accepted': TTL_DUPLICATE,
+        "/search/package\?match=\[@project='([^']+)'\]$": TTL_LONG,
+        # Potentially expire the latest_updated since it will be the only way to
+        # tell after an adi staging is removed. For now just cache the calls
+        # that occur in rapid succession.
+        "/search/project/id\?match=starts-with\(@name,'([^']+)\:'\)$": TTL_DUPLICATE,
+        # List of all projects may change, but relevant ones rarely.
+        '/source$': TTL_LONG,
+        # Sources will be expired with project, could be done on package level.
+        '/source/([^/?]+)(?:\?.*)?$': TTL_LONG,
+        # Project will be marked changed when packages are added/removed.
+        '/source/([^/]+)/_meta$': TTL_LONG,
+        '/source/([^/]+)/(?:[^/]+)/(?:_meta|_link)$': TTL_LONG,
+        # Handles clearing local cache on package deletes. Lots of queries like
+        # updating project info, comment, and package additions.
+        '/source/([^/]+)/(?:[^/?]+)(?:\?[^/]+)?$': TTL_LONG,
+        # Presumably users are not interweaving in short windows.
+        '/statistics/latest_updated': TTL_SHORT,
+    }
+
+    last_updated = {}
+
+    @staticmethod
+    def init():
+        Cache.patterns = []
+        for pattern in Cache.PATTERNS:
+            Cache.patterns.append(re.compile(pattern))
+
+        # Replace http_request with wrapper function which needs a stored
+        # version of the original function to call.
+        if not hasattr(osc.core, '_http_request'):
+            osc.core._http_request = osc.core.http_request
+            osc.core.http_request = http_request
review_comments.body: you like monkey patching, do you? :)

review_comments.body:
Presumably the config file changing while a process is running and instantiating multiple `Manager42`/`ReviewBot` instances is just a waste. As such would it make more sense to load the config once as a class variable instead of parsing for each new instance? I did this when I incorporated your config patch into #614 (see https://github.com/openSUSE/osc-plugin-factory/pull/614/commits/1fc8ce3905f20cbf3afe28159a6ae63285d2b1d2).

Given that you had used this same style for a potential `ReviewBot` config, does it make more sense to abstract as a separate config utility that both can use? In the same fashion as `osc.conf`. Although after writing that I remembered `osclib/conf.py` which populates `osc.conf`. Either way I imagine this code might be better to be shared?

And I see `# FIXME: add to ToolBase and rebase Manager42 on that`. Alright. I only saw `biarchtool.py` using `ToolBase` so I didn't use for #628 , should I rebase on that as well? If this is to be used by `ReviewBot` should it be rebased on `ToolBase` or perhaps just call a static method to retrieve config?
